_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The case of a gentleman who has gone for: Swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress
Glorify themselves and put others down
Become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity
The person in need of heartwood (a causa: Pass over the heartwood, softwood, bark, and shoots
Cut off the branches and leaves and depart imagining they were heartwood
Cut off the shoots and depart imagining they were heartwood
Cut off the bark and depart imagining it was heartwood
Cut out the softwood and depart imagining it was heartwood
Cut out just the heartwood and depart knowing it was heartwood
The mendicant who has grabbed the branch: Glorify themselves and put others down
Become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity
The mendicant who has grabbed the shoots: Not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for
Don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that
Not become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity
Become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding their accomplishment in ethics
The mendicant who has grabbed the bark o: Not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for
Don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that
Not become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity
Become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that accomplishment in immersion
The mendicant who has grabbed the softwo: Not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for
Don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that
Not become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity
Glorify themselves and put others down on account of that
Become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding that knowledge and vision
The mendicant who has achieved permanent: Not happy with that, and haven’t got all they wished for
Don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of that
Not become indulgent and fall into negligence regarding those possessions, honor, and popularity
Impossible for that mendicant to fall away from that irreversible liberation.
